Context:
Program Name: Honours Bachelor of Business Administration (Hospitality)
Code: H311
Credential: Honours Bachelor's Degree
Duration: 4 years (8 semesters plus 2 co-op terms)
Method of Study: Full-time
Starting Months: September
Domestic Tuition: $9,012.00
International Tuition: $20,579.00
Centre: Hospitality & Culinary Arts
School: Hospitality & Tourism Management
Location: St. James Campus
Experiential Learning: Co-op (Paid)
Fall 2023 Delivery: Hybrid for Semesters 1, 3, 5; Online for Semester 7
Winter 2024 Delivery: Hybrid for Semesters 2, 4, 6, 8
Availability: Closed for Fall 2023 and Winter 2024 for Domestic Students, Not Available for International Students in both semesters.
Program Description: Develop exceptional decision-making and problem-solving skills to become a hospitality sector entrepreneur or business leader. Combine experiential learning through four-month paid terms working full-time in the industry.
$1000 entrance scholarship eligible.

Context:
The George Brown College offers a Honours Bachelor of Business Administration (Hospitality) program designed to teach students how to manage complex hospitality operations and become leaders in the sector. This program prepares students for management, supervisory, and administrative careers through training in various areas such as analysis and problem-solving, critical thinking, operational processes, finance, human resources, marketing, facilities, risk management, corporate social responsibility, and sustainability.

The employment prospects in the hospitality industry are outstanding with over 1.2 million people employed in Canada representing over 7% of all employment, and almost 329,000 jobs in the Greater Toronto Area alone.

The curriculum is designed to provide flexible student learning through courses offered in online and in-class hybrid format, with every student working on projects individually and with team members. Students will obtain practical experience through at least two four-month paid work placements, providing them with valuable industry connections and hands-on training. George Brown College also offers self-directed industry work experience opportunities for students to pursue.

Sources:
[1] http://www.statcan.gc.ca/tables-tableaux/sum-som/l01/cst01/econ40-eng.htm
[2] http://www.toronto.ca/toronto_facts/entertainment_tourism.htm

Context:
The text provides information about the career opportunities and educational pathways for graduates of the Hospitality degree program at the college. Some key facts include:

* Students obtain practical experience and develop skills through co-op programs, which can lead to full-time employment with starting salaries up to $50,000.
* Graduates can pursue career opportunities in various sectors of the hospitality industry, such as travel, accommodations, food service, sports and recreation, and assembly and event management.
* The program offers a student exchange opportunity with Manchester Metropolitan University in Manchester, England for eligible students in their second year of study.
* Graduates can continue their studies by pursuing a master's degree or postgraduate education at partner universities such as IMI, Manchester University, University of Guelph, Toronto Metropolitan University, University of Waterloo, Royal Roads University, and Queen's University.
* Students with a two-year Hospitality diploma can upgrade to the Honours Bachelor of Business Administration (Hospitality) program through articulation options, provided they have a minimum 3.0 GPA and class grades of 73 per cent or higher.

Therefore, the extracted information would be:

* Career opportunities in travel, accommodations, food service, sports and recreation, and assembly and event management sectors.
* Student exchange opportunity with Manchester Metropolitan University in Manchester, England.
* Postgraduate education options at partner universities such as IMI, Manchester University, University of Guelph, Toronto Metropolitan University, University of Waterloo, Royal Roads University, and Queen's University.
* Articulation options for students with a two-year Hospitality diploma to upgrade to the Honours Bachelor of Business Administration (Hospitality) program.

Context:
Extracted Information:

The text provides information about the Pathways from Diploma to Degree Program offered at the college with the following details:

1. Required Courses: The list of required courses for each semester in Years 1, 2, and 3, including their codes and names.

Year 1:
- Semester 1: HOST 1195 (Introduction to Business Management), HOST 1196 (Organizational Behaviour), HOST 1197 (Skills for Success), ACCT 1201 (Financial Accounting), COMM 1201 (Business Communication), HOSF 1145 (Sanitation, online certificate), HOSF 1146 (Emergency First Aid/Heartsaver CPR, weekend course), and an Elective.
- Semester 2: HOST 1204 (Introduction to the Global Hospitality Industry), ACCT 1202 (Managerial Accounting), HRM 1201 (Human Resources Management), MARK 1201 (Marketing Management), and an Elective.

Year 2:
- Semester 3: BBUS 1007 (Macroeconomics: Canada in Global Environment), HOST 2108 (Tourism in a Global Community), HOST 2109 (Food and Beverage Management), HOST 1302 (Accommodation Management), and an Elective.
- Semester 4: BBUS 1006 (Microeconomics: Canada in Global Environment), HOST 2103 (Customer Service), HOST 3114 (Business and Hospitality Law), and HOST 3103 (Event Planning and Management).

Year 3:
- Work Experience: HCOP 1001 (Co-op Work Term I, minimum 14 weeks: 520 hours).

Year 3 to Year 6:
- Semester 5: HOST 2113 (Financial Management), HOST 3102 (Consumer Behaviour), HOST 3119 (Decision-Making), COMM 2201 (Intercultural Communications), LHUM 1204 or LHUM 1224 (Spanish I or Mandarin I).
- Semester 6: HOST 3113 (Strategic Revenue Management), HOST 4111 (Competitive Strategy for Integrated Hospitality Enterprises), STAT 1202 (Statistics), and LHUM 1214 or LHUM 1225 (Spanish II or Mandarin II).

Each semester includes an Elective. The courses are a mix of Host, Accounting, Human Resources Management, Marketing, Hospitality Law, Event Planning and Management, Statistics, and Liberal Studies Electives. Some courses have prerequisites like minimum duration (weeks or hours) and availability in different languages (Spanish or Mandarin).

No information related to the specific program offered by the college is provided in the text.

Context:
The text provides information about the elective courses and requirements for graduation in a hospitality program at the college. Here are some key factual extracts from the text:

1. There are various elective Liberal Studies courses, which include courses such as HCOP 2001 (Co-op Work Term II), HOST 4101 (Research: Concepts and Application I), HOST 4104 (Sustainability and Corporate Social Responsibility), HOST 4007 (Innovation and Creativity), HOST 3117 (Sales Management), HOST 4102 (New Venture Development), HOST 4103 (E-Hospitality), HOST 4112 (Research: Concepts and Application II), HOST 4113 (Cases in Global Business Management), HOST 4117 (Managing Uncertainty: Enterprise Risk Management), and HOST 4118 (Managing Uncertainty: Crisis Management).
2. The text mentions that there are seven-week courses for HOST 4117 and HOST 4118.
3. Students must have a minimum cumulative grade point average of 2.3 to graduate, with a passing grade being D.
4. Liberal studies courses are an essential part of the program and help students develop skills in critical analysis, problem-solving, communication, and awareness of societal issues.
5. The learning outcomes for graduates include assessing environmental impact on the hospitality industry, explaining research results, applying management knowledge, justifying decisions, interpreting data, presenting information clearly, displaying ethical behavior, designing marketing strategies, and keeping current in the field.
6. The text does not provide any information about tuition or fees.

Context:
Program Tuition and Fees:
- Domestic Tuition for Fall 2022: $9,012.00
- International Tuition for Fall 2023: $20,579.00
- Additional costs (tuition, materials, student service and ancillary fees) for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2022 and Fall 2023: $575
- Fees do not include cost of co-op work term

Financial Assistance:
- Approved for OSAP funding for applicants who meet eligibility criteria.

Admission Requirements:
- Ontario Secondary School Diploma with six grade 12 university (U) or university/college (M) courses, including grade 12 (U) English and any grade 12 (U) mathematics.
- A grade of 60% or higher in English and math, and an overall average of 65% in six grade 12 (U) or (M) courses is required.
- Recommended courses: basic computer software applications.
- For mature students (19 years of age or older and no OSSD), a grade 12 (U) English, grade 12 (U) mathematics, a grade of 65% or higher in English and math is required. Post-secondary courses in English and mathematics will be considered.
- Recommended courses: basic computer software applications.
- No mature student testing available for degree programs; mature applicants must have the English and math credits required.

Context:
* George Brown College offers degree programs with requirements for mature applicants to have English and math credits.
* English language proficiency is required with specific score minimums for various tests.
* Course exemptions may be granted based on college or university credits.
* International Students have country-specific admission requirements.
* Applicants with a two-year Hospitality diploma may consider the Honours Bachelor of Business Administration (Hospitality) bridging program.
* Health Policy: Allergens, including nuts, dairy and shellfish, are used in practical labs. George Brown College is sensitive to religious observances but may not meet specific dietary laws related to halal and kosher foods.
* Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges.
* The college has been granted a seven-year consent by the Ministry of Colleges and Universities starting December 19, 2019.
* Students admitted during the period of consent will have the opportunity to complete the program within a reasonable time frame.

International Students:
- Can apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
- Should visit the How to Apply page for more application information.
- Can contact Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit the Admissions web page for inquiries about domestic admission requirements, deadlines, and processes.
- Can contact Financial Aid Office at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or visit the Financial Aid web page for financial inquiries.
- Can contact chcastudentsupport@georgebrown.ca for general School of Hospitality and Tourism Management related inquiries.
- Can call the Contact Centre at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002 for more information about George Brown College.
- Can contact international recruitment representatives specializing by country of origin through the International Contact Us page or book a virtual meeting or submit an inquiry.
- Can join Discovery Day to learn more about programs, facilities, and meet with representatives.
- Can explore related programs like Tourism and Hospitality Management (H130), Hospitality – Hotel Operations Management (H133), and Event Planning (H141).
- Can book campus tour or info session.
- Can sign up to receive tailored resources to make application process easier.
